articles.headline: Perils in Philosophy of Austerity in the U.S.
articles.snippet: Without a new budget agreement, impending cuts could inhibit the federal government’s ability to do its basic job.
articles.abstract: Without a new budget agreement, impending cuts could inhibit the federal government’s ability to do its basic job.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Grand Bargain is off the table. Thank goodness for that.

articles.headline: Fed Extends Stimulus as Growth Stumbles
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve said it would keep its campaign of asset purchases and low interest rates intact. The central bank’s statement contained no surprises, and the stock market barely budged.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve said it would keep its campaign of asset purchases and low interest rates intact. The central bank’s statement contained no surprises, and the stock market barely budged.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is still waiting for clear evidence that the economy can grow decently without its help.

articles.headline: Mobile Ads Fuel a Jump in Profit at Facebook
articles.snippet: Profits doubled in the third quarter, and the social network reported that mobile ads now accounted for about half its advertising revenue.
articles.abstract: Profits doubled in the third quarter, and the social network reported that mobile ads now accounted for about half its advertising revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Perhaps Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, should ditch the hoodie and dress up as a mobile phone for Halloween.

articles.headline: Looking for a Way Around Keystone XL, Canadian Oil Hits the Rails
articles.snippet: Despite higher costs, Canadian oil companies are rapidly expanding their ability to transport crude by rail, hoping to tap hungry markets in Asia.
articles.abstract: Despite higher costs, Canadian oil companies are rapidly expanding their ability to transport crude by rail, hoping to tap hungry markets in Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Over the past two years, environmentalists have chained themselves to the White House fence and otherwise coalesced around stopping the Keystone XL pipeline as their top priority in the fight against global warming.

articles.headline: From Anonymity to Scourge of Wall Street
articles.snippet: A onetime engineer who earned his law degree at night has been behind the government’s campaign to punish Wall Street for the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: A onetime engineer who earned his law degree at night has been behind the government’s campaign to punish Wall Street for the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: The architect of a recent legal crackdown on Wall Street’s dubious mortgage practices was not the attorney general, a United States attorney or a rising star in the Justice Department. Instead, it was Leon W. Weidman, an unassuming 69-year-old career prosecutor, toiling away in anonymity 3,000 miles from Washington.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Activists Feel Powerful Wrath as Russia Guards Its Arctic Claims
articles.snippet: The detained crew of a Greenpeace ship appears to have grossly underestimated Russia’s readiness to assert — and expand — its sovereignty in an Arctic region potentially rich with natural resources.
articles.abstract: The detained crew of a Greenpeace ship appears to have grossly underestimated Russia’s readiness to assert — and expand — its sovereignty in an Arctic region potentially rich with natural resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Gizem Akhan, 24, was about to begin her final year studying the culinary arts at Yeditepe University in Istanbul. Tomasz Dziemianczuk, 36, took a vacation from his job as a cultural adviser at the University of Gdansk in Poland that has now unexpectedly turned into an unpaid leave of absence.

articles.headline: N.S.A. Said to Tap Google and Yahoo Abroad
articles.snippet: Unbeknown to Google and Yahoo, the National Security Agency and its British counterpart have tapped into the search engines abroad, where data collection faces less oversight.
articles.abstract: Unbeknown to Google and Yahoo, the National Security Agency and its British counterpart have tapped into the search engines abroad, where data collection faces less oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency and its British counterpart have apparently tapped the fiber-optic cables connecting Google’s and Yahoo’s overseas servers and are copying vast amounts of email and other information, according to accounts of documents leaked by the former agency contractor Edward J. Snowden.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Claire Cain Miller and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Tap on Merkel Provides Peek at Vast Spy Net
articles.snippet: The National Security Agency’s monitoring is not limited to politicians like Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany — it also includes party leaders and aides, and it’s all part of efforts to gain an edge over other nations.
articles.abstract: The National Security Agency’s monitoring is not limited to politicians like Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany — it also includes party leaders and aides, and it’s all part of efforts to gain an edge over other nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was not obvious to the National Security Agency a dozen years ago that Angela Merkel, a rising star as the leader of the Christian Democratic Union, was a future chancellor of Germany.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: No U.S. Action, So States Move on Privacy Law
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in 10 states have passed more than two dozen privacy laws this year on phone tracking, the use of drones and other topics, as support for limits on surveillance has grown.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in 10 states have passed more than two dozen privacy laws this year on phone tracking, the use of drones and other topics, as support for limits on surveillance has grown.
articles.lead_paragraph: State legislatures around the country, facing growing public concern about the collection and trade of personal data, have rushed to propose a series of privacy laws, from limiting how schools can collect student data to deciding whether the police need a warrant to track cellphone locations.

articles.headline: Bitcoin Pursues the Mainstream
articles.snippet: Advocates of the digital currency bitcoin say it is ready to emerge from its fringe status and become a common method of retail payment.
articles.abstract: Advocates of the digital currency bitcoin say it is ready to emerge from its fringe status and become a common method of retail payment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The currency known as bitcoin — a much-hyped and much-doubted type of digital cash that can be bought with traditional money — has mostly attracted attention for its popularity in the black market, and for its wildly gyrating valuation.

articles.headline: Syria Destroys Chemical Sites, Inspectors Say
articles.snippet: While Syria met an important deadline, it still has 1,290 metric tons of chemical weapons it must destroy by mid-2014, inspectors said.
articles.abstract: While Syria met an important deadline, it still has 1,290 metric tons of chemical weapons it must destroy by mid-2014, inspectors said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s ability to produce chemical weapons has been destroyed and its remaining toxic armaments secured, weapons inspectors said Thursday, as President Bashar al-Assad has offered unexpectedly robust cooperation, at least so far, with a Russian-United States accord to dismantle his arsenal.

articles.headline: Time Warner Left Bruised in Fee Battle With CBS
articles.snippet: The cable company lost 306,000 television subscribers in the third quarter, hurt by a contract dispute that resulted in a blackout of CBS programming.
articles.abstract: The cable company lost 306,000 television subscribers in the third quarter, hurt by a contract dispute that resulted in a blackout of CBS programming.
articles.lead_paragraph: The CBS blackout in homes with Time Warner Cable ended in early September. But the damage from the feud is still being tallied up — and it may be lasting.

articles.headline: In Shadows, Hints of a Life and Even a Job for Snowden
articles.snippet: Edward J. Snowden, a former National Security Agency contractor who received temporary asylum in Russia, will start work on Friday at an Internet company, a lawyer said.
articles.abstract: Edward J. Snowden, a former National Security Agency contractor who received temporary asylum in Russia, will start work on Friday at an Internet company, a lawyer said.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — On very rare occasions, almost always at night, Edward J. Snowden leaves his secret, guarded residence here, somewhere, in Russia. He is always under close protection. He spends his days learning the language and reading. He recently finished “Crime and Punishment.”

articles.headline: F.A.A. Moves to Ease Electronics Ban, Opening the Runways to Angry Birds
articles.snippet: The change, expected before the end of the year, will allow passengers on most flights to use tablets, MP3 players and other personal electronic devices.
articles.abstract: The change, expected before the end of the year, will allow passengers on most flights to use tablets, MP3 players and other personal electronic devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The days of airline passengers being hounded to turn off their tablets or e-readers for takeoff and landing are coming to an end.

articles.headline: Reshuffling at Time Inc. to Set Table for Spinoff
articles.snippet: The appointment was part of a reorganization of Time Inc. as it prepares to be spun off from its parent company, Time Warner.
articles.abstract: The appointment was part of a reorganization of Time Inc. as it prepares to be spun off from its parent company, Time Warner.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seeking to increase revenue by building a closer partnership between business and the newsroom, Time Inc. said on Thursday that the editors of its individual magazines would report directly to the company’s business side for the first time in its history, instead of the editor in chief of Time Inc.
